name: Poppy Ptarmigan---Original woodcut
description:
This little bird print doesn't have a scientific background. I am looking for names for my first baby, and, if it had been a girl, I would have liked to have called her "Poppy Ptarmigan" so that every time I drew either of these living things, I would have thought of her. But, it's a boy! So, this piece can still be for him but I will be making an, "Oriole Ammonite" woodcut next.

Original color-reduction woodcut
10" x 11"
edition of 14

name: Chinampas---Original Woodcut
description:
Chinampas is not a word you hear everyday in the English language and probably not even in the Spanish language. Chinampas are an early form of aquaculture, floating agricultural islands that provided food for up to 1/3 of the population of ancient Tenochtitl√°n during the Aztec era. 

People would harvest the food with canoes, and it meant that the land could be used for housing, stores and all other structures a civilization needed. I suppose that creating an island could be easier than terracing a mountain for veggies?

4 block color-reduction woodcut
image size 28.5" x 39"
edition of 7

name: Monarchs Mounted on Bamboo
description:
Monarchs are a flagship butterfly in North America. Who can imagine a time when they may not flutter about? Monarch larvae feed almost exclusively on milkweed. As we all know, our world is getting more and more crowded which means less room for milkweed and in turn less room for Monarchs.

Deforestation of their winter roosting sites has created hardship. They roost along the sunny coast of California and a mountainous region of Mexico. Their California roosts are ideal for them but also for humans who crave sunny skies and rolling ocean front real estate. Their favored trees in Mexico are also favored by loggers, making both areas particularly vulnerable.

8x10 block, no framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.

name: San Fran Shipwrecks---Original Woodcut
description:
This large skinny woodcut is titled, "San Fran Shipwrecks." As many as 600 ships were abandoned in the harbor during the gold rush era. The owners thought there was more value in California's shiny veins than in their vessels and left their boats to explore the state. 

When the current financial district was built up, the sunken ships made a good base for the tall buildings and condos that were constructed. But, during new excavation projects, often an archaeologist is called in to evaluate the scene because interesting historical vessels are regularly found. The image for the boat that I used is a whaling ship named, "Lydia." She was discovered in 1980. It felt good to put a buried whaling ship in the piece. 

Image size 16x32"
edition size 12

name: San Marco Strata---Original Woodcut
description:
Have a long skinny wall that needs some art? I am marking this piece on sale because you may have a square shaped wall that needs 2 long skinny woodcuts and it goes so nicely with my new piece, "San Fran Shipwrecks."

When I was in Venice I learned that much of the place is built upon huge piers that were then layered with limestone, marble and monuments. While walking across the top layer, I couldn't help but think about what lay below. San Marco Strata gives a glimpse of what the layers of Venice may look like.

edition of 7
16x32"

name: Puffin Square Bowl
description:
These two puffins are ignoring each other, but, I think they actually like one other...

I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece.

8" x 2"

name: Puffin bowl
description:
Puffins are some of the best little birds, with their large beaks and small wings...it's amazing they can lift themselves off the ground and fly around!

I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece.

The thunder of these beasts can almost be heard through the porcelain. Poor rhinos, I feel so bad that these creatures are in such peril because of their horns. 

I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece.

description:

Hand-printed etching with watercolor on top. Fits nicely in an 8x10 frame.

I used the blue banded octopi as my model for this etching which is a tiny Australian species that is very venomous.

Hand-printed etching with watercolor on top. Fits nicely in an 8x10 frame.

Little pinkish owl with a large moon. 

Hand-printed etching with watercolor on top. Fits nicely in an 8x10 frame.

name: Walrus Porcelain Dish

I hand painted and carved the surface, then rubbed underglaze into the lines after the first firing. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you put it on a stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece.

Made out of dark brown clay with a porcelain slip on top. I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece. The back and the front are both decorated.

7.25" wide x 2" tall.

Made out of dark brown clay with a porcelain slip on top. I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece. The back and the front are both decorated.

name: Devonian Reef Platter
description:
The Devonian period is known as the age of fishes because new sea life was exploding and fish were evolving to fill many ecological niches. It was a good time to be a large fish, maybe not so great of a time to be a smaller fish.

Made out of dark brown clay with a porcelain slip on top. I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece. The back and the front are both decorated.

11" square platter

Made out of dark brown clay with a porcelain slip on top. I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece. The back and the front are both decorated.

11" square

name: Lionfish medium bumpy bowl
description:
I am bringing my woodcut ideas into some of my new clay pieces. Lionfish are such a stunning critter, but, are highly invasive eating up colorful reef fish all over our southern seas. This lionfish is a little loppy so I am marking it down from $65 to $55.

Made out of dark brown clay with a porcelain slip on top. I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece. The back and the front are both decorated.

7.25" wide x 2" tall

name: Hedgehog bumpy bowl
description:
A little turned over hedgehog, maybe it wants a tummy rub? I think it looks a little bit like a cave painting. This piece is a tad warpy, so I am marking down from $150 to $125.

Made out of dark brown clay with a porcelain slip on top. I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece. The back and the front are both decorated.

8.5" wide x 4" tall

name: LARGE Baltimore Animalia mounted on bamboo
description:
For all who love Baltimore...Ravens, Orioles, Blue Crabs and the infamous Natty Boh adorn this piece.

I sold out of this edition and am now offering it as a reproduction. I have 1 11x14" in stock, but it can be made to order.

No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.

name: Narwhals mounted on bamboo!
description:
The latin name for Narwhal is Monodon monoceros which means "one tooth, one horn." Even though some of these tusky whales actually have 2 horns! Narwhals live in the Arctic and depend on dense sea ice for survival. Orcas are the Narwhals biggest predator, but, they cannot forge easily into the thick frozen seas. And, if the northwest passage becomes a viable trade route, ships will be trekking into the seas where these shy mammals live. Also, Narwhals largest food source is halibut. They live about 4,000 feet below the surface, if the fish move, the Narwhals will have to find a different dinner. Scientists don't know the impact of warming temperatures, but, these whales could be the first effected due to their icy quarters. 

8x8 reproduction mounted on bamboo

name: Invasive Corn mounted on bamboo!
description:
Corn is food...but some "food" you may not realize is "corn." (common ingredients that are derived from maize are maltodextrin, dextrose, mono- and di-glycerides, sorbitol, MSG, xanthan gum, and of course the lovely corn syrup, and high fructose corn syrup) and now biofuels.
There is much debate about biofuels and if they are sustainable. 

This image portrays a scene where trucks have to transport their own corn for fuel to get around. I highly recommend Michael Pollan's "The Omnivore's Dilemma" if you are interested in corn production, processed foods, and ecologically minded farming/farmers.

I sold out of this edition and am now offering it as an 8x10 reproduction mounted on sustainably harvested bamboo.

No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.

name: Nile Perch mounted on bamboo
description:
The Nile Perch has decimated chiclid populations in African lakes. These "leviathans" as they are often called because of their enormous size, are responsible for the loss of over 200 species of haplochromine chiclids.

Nile Perch were introduced as a food source for people who live near the lakes, but, the fish processing industry is booming, and feeding China and Japan has raised the price of the fish flesh SO HIGH, people in the area can no longer afford it. Stories of people picking from the scraps thrown out by processing plants are well documented.

name: Mars bowl
description:
I am having a ton of fun making this planetary tableware. Why Mars and Venus? I have an affinity for the color red and I think that Venus tableware is the perfect wedding gift (as the mythic Venus encompasses love.)

I currently have 2 Mars bowls in stock. Approximately 8.5" wide (including rim) and 3.5" tall. These are a tad bit warpy so I am marking the price down from $150 to $125

name: Irish Elk Ceramic Dish
description:
Irish Elk were the largest deer species to have ever lived! They had a rack up to 12 feet across. They went extinct about 8,000 years ago, possibly due to humans or possible due to those giant horns.

Made out of dark brown clay with a porcelain slip on top. I hand painted and carved the surface. It is food and dishwasher safe, or you can hang it on the wall or put it on a plate stand and call it art! One of a kind handmade piece. The back and the front are both decorated.

8.25" square

name: Catch and Release Mounted on Bamboo
description:
Many Americans thought high isolated mountain lakes from California to Colorado were being wasted because of the lack of fish, so, as the railroad became more popular, people and fish were transported at the same time across the states and fish were dumped into any and all bodies of water along the way.

Ariel stocking became a preferred way of introducing fish after WWII. Stockpiles of military equipment were put to use. Very little research was conducted on the effectiveness of "tossing trout" I thought the process had been eliminated, but, many states still are dumping fish from the sky today. As far out as it sounds, it is a true story!

I sold out of this edition and am now offering it as an 8x12 reproduction mounted on sustainably harvested bamboo.

No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.

name: Museum Squatters---Original Woodcut
description:
Another Starling! I am pursuing my dream to make a non-fiction picture book about the history of starlings and how they became an invasive animal. 

This piece shows the Natural History Museum of New York City which is where the first 70 birds that were introduced into the US took up residence. I love the irony of the birds choosing the natural history museum. 

color-reduction woodcut
image size 17‚Äù x 13 ‚Äù
edition size 11

options.name: Framed in brown burl frame allow 3 weeks

name: Sturnus Vulgaris Lithographica---Original Woodcut
description:
This little starry bird just flew off the drying rack in the studio. Part of the picture book I have been wildly working on for ages. 

Starlings are a pesky little bird, but, as with anything, there are many shades of grey in between the peskiness. 

Original woodcut 10x11" edition of 16. There is a framed option as well, please allow at least 2 weeks for delivery on the framed one.

The 2nd picture is of the drawing on the block, the 3rd picture shows the first 2 colors of the woodcut and the 4th picture shows printing the last black layer.

options.name: In a brown wood burl frame allow 2 week for delivery

name: Tidal Medley---Original Woodcut
description:
"Tidal Medley" is a celebratory woodcut about the diversity of the Southern US seas. Our oceans are sacred, special places that need our protection. The amazing watery wonderland off the coast of Georgia teems with wildlife. Right now the sea is coughing. Large mammals living in the ocean are filled with heavy metals, shrimp are full of poison and women of child bearing age are advised not to eat fish. Our blue heart needs our help now so lets do our part. Reduce our trash, reduce our consumption and give our time, energy and thoughts to the ocean. Lets keep this seaside wilderness strong and healthy.  

edition of 8
image size 28 x 39 inches

options.name: pay it off in six months @$300/month

name: Rookery Patrol---Original Woodcut
description:
"Rookery Patrol" is about the amazing diversity of the Southern US Marshes. While visiting Georgia, I found out that gators actually make themselves at home below bird rookeries. While immediately that seems like it would have no benefit to the birds, the gators actually chase away other predators such as weasels, raccoons, and possums. While the gators are not the perfect neighbor, they will snack on a baby bird, it is more symbiotic than expected. 

edition of 6
image size 28 x 39 inches

name: Water Hyacinth, Pickerel Weed---Original Woodcut
description:
I made a series of prints about endangered animals where the edition size is the number of animals left in the world. With this linocut I went to the opposite end of the spectrum and made a piece about the invasive water hyacinth which is taking over waterways, clogging drain pipes, and covering lakes and streams, which ends up depleting the water of oxygen and choking out all animals and other plants living there. The largest problem is that these plants are extremely vigorous and prolific. They can double their population in just two weeks!

I will be making oodles of these prints and they all will be a little different. The edition will go like this "1/many, 2/many, 3/many..." I currently have 4 with this brown/green color scheme.

image size is 10.5 x 10.5inches

name: Cat Pack, assorted Kitty cards
description:
I put these kitties on cards so that you can send them to all your friends. Discounts for ordering bulk quantities, $3.95 for one card $10 for 3! or $20 for 6! All come with envelopes.

Printed on eco-friendly 50% recycled FSC certified paper

name: Insatiable Winged Lions---Original Woodcut
description:
This massive (34x48") lionfish woodcut was started in Venice, Italy and finished in Ithaca, NY. The title is, "Insatiable Winged Lions---Kings of Coral" The latin name for lionfish is Pterois volitans which means "winged fin" so it totally fits the Venetian reference. I had no idea when I went to Venice to make a lionfish woodcut that it would actually make sense.

These fish are reeking havoc on reefs and small fish populations from the Caribbean to as far north as Massachusetts. A few amazing statistics about the fishes appetites, their stomachs can stretch 30x in size and one large lionfish was recorded eating 20 small fishes in a 30 minute period. Our best hope for population control now seems to be serving lionfish on dinner plates. The only thing with a more insatiable appetite is a human.

If your order this huge beauty, it will come packaged very carefully in a large sono tube used for pouring concrete. Perfect for shipping art.

name: Deep Sea Delicacy mounted on bamboo!
description:
Anglerfish, Spookfish, Rubber ducks glowing diatoms and Hammerhead Sharks are the subjects of this 8x8" bamboo block. Your walls are asking for a spookfish.

No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.

name: Red Winged White Bird mounted on Bamboo!
description:
People use to believe that black birds were white, until they fell into a chimney and turned black from the soot! A simple little tale turned into sweet little woodcut and now available as a reproduction on bamboo!

8x8" No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.

name: Puffin Chase Original Woodcut LAST ONE!
description:
One more Newfoundland dog chasing a flock of puffins down the road. This has been a popular piece. Just one left of the edition! Get it before somebody else does.

Ches's is a famous fish and chips restaurant serving fresh cod daily. You probably won't see a Newfoundland dog herding puffin on the sidewalk, but, anything is possible.

I stayed just up the block from this place during my residency and loved the building color and the plate glass windows so took an afternoon and drew this scene on a block while sitting on the opposite sidewalk, with a poodle dog, not a newfoundland dog.

color-reduction woodcut 
image size 19‚Äù x 23.75‚Äù 
edition size 8 only one left

options.name: payment plan pay for it in 6 installments

name: Plan B---Mirrors in Space
description:
Interfering with sunlight is one possibility of a large scale geo-engineering project. The idea is to actually shoot hundreds of thousands of mirrors into space to reflect the sunlight "out" instead of "in."
"Scientists estimated that reflecting less than 1% of sunlight back into space could compensate for warming generated by all greenhouse gases emitted since the industrial revolution." (source The Guardian.)
We have entered the sci-fi world of space debris as a solution to climate change.

image size 19 x 23.75"
edition of 8

Deforestation of their winter roosting sites has created hardship. They roost along the sunny coast of California and a mountainous region of Mexico. name: Pinetree Invasion---Original Woodcut
description:
People thought the New Zealand hillsides were eroding away, so they dropped Lodgepole Pines from helicopters in order to 'preserve' the landscape. What ended up happening in reality was the trees loved New Zealand and spread like wildfire across the country and now are considered a pest. 

I couldn't make up my mind (or I ran out of ink when I was printing) so there are two different background colors. One is a nice forest green and the other is swell and purpley. Please scroll down the screen to see both versions. 

The edition size is 11 and I have 5 dark purples and 6 light purples.

color-reduction woodcut
image size 27.5‚Äù x 17‚Äù

name: Starling Stockpiling---Original Woodcut
description:
Starlings like to take more than they need, they like to raid other birds nests and kick out the little ones to make room for their own fuzzy chicklets. They are smart and they steal. Elliot has lost a cache of tennis balls due to the greedyness of black spotted birdies. 

All while the rats play.

color-reduction woodcut 
image size 13‚Äù x 17 ‚Äù
$500 unframed

name: Godwit original woodcut
description:
Where do the little Godwits go? They turn into large horned ungulates of course! OK, so they myth may not be these exact creature transformations, but, it was believed that birds changed during the winter months. 

SOME REAL FACTS:Little Godwits have an intense migration route flying from Alaska to New Zealand and Australia every year! Fly on little friends. 

color-reduction woodcut 
image size 5‚Äù x 5.5‚Äù

name: Cats that Love mounted on Bamboo!
description:

I sold out of this edition and am now offering it as an 8x10 reproduction mounted on sustainably harvested bamboo.

No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.

name: Starlings and Saguaros---Original woodcut
description:
Tuscon Arizona is the setting of this desert woodcut. Starlings threaten native bird populations who make nesting cavities. Starlings love to nest in holes, but they are not capable of making their own. They take over nests of gila woodpeckers who prefer to nest in saguaro cactus, leaving the woodpecker homeless.

color-reduction woodcut 
image size 19‚Äù x 23.75 ‚Äù

name: Seahorse Latitudes---Original woodcut
description: 10 x 11" color reduction woodcut an edition of 17. These 3 Hippocampus' were made for a collaboration between Pyramid Atlantic, The Sargasso Sea Alliance and a number of artists who were invited to make art about the animals that reside in the Sargasso. The title, "SEAhorse Latitudes" refers to the location of the sea. Back in the day when humans were the seafaring type, this location was called the dreaded horse latitudes because the weather was so calm, often boats would be stuck for days. It is thought horses were sacrificed to conserve supplies and water on board when stuck in the Sargasso. Tweet

name: Landseer and Murres---Original woodcut
description:
Landseers are a type of black and white Newfoundland. I thought it would humorous to make a Landseer have the same markings as the native Murre. 

The background shows Signal Hill and the Battery Point neighborhood in St. John's. It is my attempt at portraying the adorable "jelly bean" houses in the background. Newfoundlanders back in the day would buy one can of paint and paint their boat and their house with the same paint. Since it was better to have a brightly colored boat at sea, the houses just ended up vibrantly colored as well.

color-reduction woodcut 
image size 19‚Äù x 23.75‚Äù 
edition size 8

name: Shakesperean Flock---Original woodcut
description:
This piece is about Eugene in his English garden surrounded by all the birds mentioned in Shakespeare's plays. 

The other two invasive US birds in this woodcut are Mute Swans and European Sparrows. Mute swans were intentionally introduced to the United States for display as decorative waterfowl in public parks and private estates. Sparrows may also have been a gift from Mr. Scheffelin.

The parrot and ostrich never became an invasive animal, although there is a large feral population of parrots in Florida, it is not the fault of Eugene. 

color-reduction woodcut 
image size 19‚Äù x 23.75 
2 color schemes, one that is more "grey" and another that is more "red"

name: Right Whale Breach---Original multi block woodcut
description:
There are three right whale populations, the North Atlantic right whales (which are critically endangered) the North Pacific right whales (which may be more endangered than the North Atlantic) and the Southern right whales (which are happy, fat, and well populated.) Some theories about why the northern population is small include entanglement in fishing nets, ship to whale collisions, and loss of habitat. 

The edition of 97 corresponds to the number of North Atlantic calving females left in our oceans. Hopefully, by the time I print out 97 whales, there will be double the number of calving females and I can make a new edition.

image size 11.5‚Äù x 15‚Äù

name: A Plane and a Crane---Original multi-block woodcut
description:
The Whooping Crane population fell to an all time low in 1942. They numbered just 15 birds but with the creative effort of dedicated individuals they are doing much better. There are now 91 breeding pairs in the wild and another 32 in captivity. 

Yes, there is an ultra light in the background. Each fall, under the auspices of the Whooping Crane Eastern Partnership, a non-profit organization named "Operation Migration," imprints a new generation of Whooping cranes on their aircraft in order to teach them a migration route from Wisconsin to Florida. Because cranes learn their migration route from their parents, the knowledge of the eastern migratory route was lost when all the birds that used that flyway disappeared. 

Operation Migration has taught 8 generations of Whooping cranes this ancient flyway. After being led south once, these birds continue to migrate back and forth on their own.

name: Devonian Reef--Original woodcut
description:
The title of this original woodcut is, "Devonian Reef---Age of Sponges." Ammonites, Trilobites, Sponges, Cnidarians, Hydrozoas, and Echinoderms wriggle about. The Devonian was a fantastic geological period commonly known as the "age of fishes" because the diversity of the finned and gilled was so great. 

This woodcut is a new long skinny size 16"x34", perfect for those narrow walls that need a little pizazz.

options.name: Pay it off in full and get it now $1100

name: Glacial Leapfrog---Original multi-block woodcut
description:
Wyoming Toads are a glacial relic. Their ancestors moved south ahead of the advancing ice swaths while a small population hunkered down in the Laramie River basin.
Wyoming toad populations in the wild are very low. They hover around 100 individuals. There is a fairly successful breeding program in captivity which has a population around 500 individuals but either way their numbers are precarious. I spoke with Val Hornyak who is a herpetologist at the Toledo zoo, she mentioned one problem too with studying toads is they are not an enigmatic mammal so finding funding can be difficult. I care about toads and how y'all do too.

name: Magic Rabbit Wildcard---Original Woodcut
description:
This woodcut was a lucky piece that came hot off the press just as spring rolled around in upstate NY.

The setting is Australia and the rabbits are hopping their way across the country. There are native Australian animals behind the "rabbit proof fence" and a magical zigzag and mismatch illusion for the bunnies to snatch a moment of fun. The two bucks in the foreground are playing, and the sulfur-crested cockatoos are fluttering in the background.

color-reduction woodcut
image size 27.5‚Äù x 17‚Äù

name: View from Llenroc---Original Woodcut
description:
Deer, Deer Everywhere yet they are not eating the multiflora roses. This year the deer demolished our peach tree, we had 11 beautiful peaches but the deer went through the fence and left us one. I planted tomatoes and kiwi berries (Which are one of my favorite northern fruits) and the deers ate them up! Plus the rhubarb plant, holly, pitcher plant, and sedums. Grr...they did not eat the rosemary, bleeding hearts, thyme and sage. Or, the numerous multi-flora rose bushes which are a prominent subject in this woodcut.

Deer are having a negative dramatic effect on forests. They eat all the understory, so trees don't have a chance to grow. I wonder what our forests are going to look like a few hundred years from now when many of our large trees die of old age, and there are no new trees to replace them? The multiflora roses are also a major problem. A walk in the woods could turn into a walk into a large thorny patch.

I wanted to pay homage to the city of Ithaca in this woodcut since I love my home. There is a little Cornell in the background, though, you may notice something just doesn't seem right, hint, the title of the piece, "A View from Llenroc."

name: Underworld Owls 5x5 mounted on bamboo!
description:
One early migration theory was that birds go underground when the weather gets foul. Owls were often portrayed as underworld guides in Egyptian mythology.

Some real facts about owls, certain species of owls do not migrate, and "burrowing" owls nest underground in abandoned mammal burrows. 

I sold out of this edition and am now offering it as a reproduction. 5 x 5" vignette of the big one.

No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.

name: Nile Perch 5x5 mounted on bamboo!
description:
The Nile Perch has decimated chiclid populations in African lakes. These "leviathans" as they are often called because of their enormous size, are responsible for the loss of over 200 species of haplochromine chiclids.

Nile Perch were introduced as a food source for people who live near the lakes, but, the fish processing industry is booming, and feeding China and Japan has raised the price of the fish flesh SO HIGH, people in the area can no longer afford it. Stories of people picking from the scraps thrown out by processing plants are well documented.

I sold out of this edition and am now offering it as an 5x5 reproduction mounted on sustainably harvested bamboo.

No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.

name: Sleeted Chicklets---Original Woodcut
description:
Antarctica has been affected by the change in climate in ways that may seem unlikely. There have been many more rainstorms on this southerly continent and some penguins are not faring too well.
It takes penguin chickies more than a month to develop the feathers they need to protect themselves from the elements and when it rains, their light down is penetrated and they can actually freeze.

color-reduction woodcut

name: Javan Rhino in the Moonlight--Original Woodcut
description:
Javan Rhinos are native to the island of Java and a few other places close to the Indonesian archipelago. They are very much in peril, their small population is even in dispute, there may be as few as 30 or as many as 60. I am an optimist, so, I made an edition of 60 to correspond with their population. A few known threats to the rhino include an invasive palm known as the Langkap Palm which takes over lowland areas where the rhino feeds, and the looming Mt. Krakotoa which last erupted in 1883 devastating the entire peninsula.

multi-block woodcut
image size 11.5‚Äù x 15‚Äù

name: Give Me Half a Tanker of Iron..--Original Woodcut
description:
People are looking for ways to capture carbon, either for credits or the greater good and Iron Fertilization is an option. The Southern Ocean Fertilization Experiment is one of the largest man-made phytoplankton blooms. Lots of Iron was dumped into the sea and it created food for algae, which bloomed, died and sank into the sea. The fallen algae sequestered carbon and supposedly stays in the deep with the carbon from the atmosphere. But, the amount of carbon that the bloom may capture, added to the amount of carbon it took to spread the iron in the first place = about 8 acres of replanted forests. 
To me it seems more worthwhile to replant our forests instead of messing with the fragile ocean ecosystem. Who knows what will happen to all the creatures in the Southern waters where the experiment is taking place. If you look carefully in the piece, the background is filled with Krill, which may seem tiny, but are very important in the ocean food chain. I stuck them in to signify the interconnectedness of large and small. How will our oceans change if large plankton blooms become a common carbon capturing tool?...All we know for sure is that the ecosystem is complex and often undocumented. 

color-reduction woodcut image size 32 x 24"

description:
This woodcut shows a rubber ducky who fell off a container ship and ended up at the bottom of the sea. 

What will these vampire-like 8-leggers do to the slimy creature? Sitting in an anemone patch, these deep sea cephalopods probably prefer to munch on something with a little more substance. With their little squid face that is a permanent frown, it is hard to tell.

name: Great Lakes Basin--Original Woodcut LAST ONE!
description:
Even though zebra mussels are annoying for feet and sewer pipes, an innovative group called the Nerites Corp. in Madison, Wisconsin are trying to use zebra mussel ‚Äútechnology‚Äù for human benefit. Nerites‚Äô goal is to create stitches made from chemicals similar to those in the mussels. if they are successful, doctors will find it easier to suture up a patient after open heart surgery, or after an accident with a saw.

This piece is a companion to Great Lakes Powder Room featuring a sunken bathtub and invasive animals in the Great Lakes.

LAST ONE! Get it while you can :)

name: Brown Booby and Brown Treesnake--Original Woodcut
description:
Brown treesnakes are thought to have been accidentally introduced onto guam after WWII as a stowaway in military ships and/or planes. They are native to the Indonesian islands, Soloman islands and Northern Australia. 

Before their introduction, Guam had many ground nesting birds but the snake has since caused nine species of bird to go extinct in the wild. Hawaii currently has no native snakes and it is important the brown treesnake does not settle there. Precautions are taken to make sure incoming planes and ships traveling from Guam are snake-free. 

color-reduction woodcut 
image size 13‚Äù x 17‚Äù

My first children's book idea was about starlings who steal, sneak, snatch, and whisk a tennis ball, (or many) away from a large white poodle...
I have decided to make the book a bit more historical, but, this poodley/birdy piece may still have a place. Maybe a side story along the way?

What a cowboy, what an intruder, what a sneaky pie. Poor Elliot, he does not have a chance against the cleverness of these birds.

Stuck through the beak, clawed, wanting to be chewed on, tennis balls are a delightful treat for starlings and poodles alike.

description:
Ahh---the black birdies are taking over a patch of corn. Luckily, a clever farmer ties red balloons all about the field to scare these pests away. The balloons act as a contemporary "scarecrow" and keep the birds at bay.

color-reduction woodcut
image size 19‚Äù x 23.75 ‚Äù

name: South of North--Original Woodcut
description:
In the far North, Polar Bears are interacting with Grizzly Bears in ways that were not possible in the recent past. Sea ice is melts away and two bear species get to play.

A $50,000 fee paid to hunt a towering white bear in the arctic revealed an unexpected twist. The catch was a little odd, it's eyes were pointed forward, there was a large hump on its back and its fur was mottled white and tan. The DNA of the bounty was tested and it was proven to be a "Pizzly" or a Polar bear/Grizzly bear cross. Good thing for the hunter, he was almost fined another thousand bucks for killing a grizzly bear (as it is illegal to kill a Grizzly, but not a Pizzly.)

Polar bears may be in trouble, their body mass is decreasing, which is a sign that an animal species is heading towards extinction and the hybrization of animals usually results in a genetic dead end. Hopefully through conservation (the polar bear has been classified as a 'threatened' animal) efforts the earth will not lose another large enigmatic mammal.

color-reduction woodcut
image size 32 x 24"

name: If Pygmy Elephants Climbed Trees--Original woodcut
description:
Komodo Dragons were discovered in 1910. What a surprise to find a 220 pound monitor lizard living on a small tropical island. How did they get to be so large? Pygmy elephant bones were found on the island of Flores, which is one of the dragons' main stomping grounds. The dragons may have grown, and grown, and grown, til they could easily eat up the elephants that resided alongside them.

If only those smart pachyderms could have learned to use their little legs for climbing, maybe they would have survived.

color-reduction woodcut
image size 13‚Äù x 17‚Äù

name: Beagle Meet Leaf Deer--Original Woodcut
description:
Leaf Deer were discovered in Myanmar in 1997. It is rare to find a warm blooded mammal new to science, but, if you are the size of a standard beagle, it is much easier to hide.

These critters stand just 20 inches tall and weigh around 25 pounds. If you hear a bark in the woods in Burma, look for deer and watch for tusks.

color-reduction woodcut
image size 13‚Äù x 17‚Äù

name: "Paradisaea apoda"---The Legless--Original woodcut
description:
Collectors in the late 19th century sent skins of the Greater Bird of Paradise to Europe and the prepared them in the fields of Aru Island without wings or feet.

The species was named Paradisaea apoda, or "legless bird of paradise", because people believed they were missing those key body parts. The birds were thought to be rather mythical creatures, floating in the atmosphere by their plumage, females laying eggs on the males back, and only touching earth to die.

color-reduction woodcut
image size 24‚Äù x 24.5‚Äù

name: Floyd's Only Friends--Original Woodcut
description:
One chilean flamingo escaped from an aviary. The bird found a suitable habitat in Saltair, Utah and is affectionately named, ‚ÄúPink Floyd.‚Äù
Jim Platt a Utah native has made it his mission to try and bring Floyd friends. He proposed that the Great Salt Lake becomes a flamingo sanctuary. Poor Floyd, living all by himself on a large salty lake.
He even has the support of 200 second graders in the area. it is probably not a good idea to give Floyd friends, as lonely as he may be, look what happened with the starling...

Squid, Octopi, Nautilus and Cuttlefish are all cephalopods, making them cousins, hence the title and the subjects.

One particularly nice visual moment in this piece is the baby squid in the background.The narrator on a Nova special about cephalopods mentioned that baby squid "are born like little white stars" which inspired the little squiggly guys in the background.

name: Ocean Sequestration mounted on Bamboo!
description: Tim Flannery's chapter titled, "Boiling the Abyss" in The Weather Makers explains what happens when humans start injecting large amounts of CO2 in the deep seas. The liquid CO2 increases the acidity of the water and makes the water warmer. The animals in the abyss have a very stable environment and are not able to protect themselves against their changing climate, many asphyxiate when they come in contact with CO2 "lakes" while animals with calcium carbonate shells disintegrate in the acidic seas. I sold out of this edition and am now offering it as an 8x10 reproduction mounted on sustainably harvested bamboo. No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal. Tweet

name: Pinniped Predicament
description: 10 x 11" color reduction woodcut edition size 18 Walrus use ice as a resting site when out to sea searching for prey and as a safe haven to raise pups, far away from the threat of polar bears and people. If the ice disappears, their safety is in danger. All animals that depend on sea ice find themselves in a bit of a "predicament." On a brighter note, one of my favorite tidbits of knowledge about walrus is they are nicknamed "tooth walkers" because when they "haul out" onto ice or land they use their teeth! Those are some strong pearly whites. Tweet

name: Narwhal 5x5 mounted on bamboo!
description:
The latin name for Narwhal is Monodon monoceros which means "one tooth, one horn." Even though some of these tusky whales actually have 2 horns! Narwhals live in the Arctic and depend on dense sea ice for survival. Orcas are the Narwhals biggest predator, but, they cannot forge easily into the thick frozen seas. And, if the northwest passage becomes a viable trade route, ships will be trekking into the seas where these shy mammals live. Also, Narwhals largest food source is halibut. They live about 4,000 feet below the surface, if the fish move, the Narwhals will have to find a different dinner. Scientists don't know the impact of warming temperatures, but, these whales could be the first effected due to their icy quarters. 5x5"

No framing needed, attaches right to the wall using a keyhole slot. This saves you megabucks on framing and makes it a super deal.
